docs.lead_paragraph: NO matter what the outcome of voting in Suffolk County on Tuesday, greater representation for the county's Hispanic residents appears certain. Two Hispanic candidates -- Ricardo Montano, a Democrat, and William R. Menendez, a Republican -- are facing each other for a seat in the County Legislature from the newly created Ninth District in Brentwood and Central Islip, where Hispanics make up 45 percent of the population. Blacks account for about 20 percent, and whites most of the remainder. There are about 14,000 registered Democrats and 8,000 Republicans.
docs.abstract: Article on legislative race between Ricardo Montano, Democrat, and William R Menendez, Republican; newly created Ninth District in Brentwood and Central Islip is about 45 percent Hispanic and first in Suffolk County, NY, in which minority voters--Hispanics and blacks--make up majority; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gloria Hernandez tries to be strong for her five children, but strength, like privacy or full stomachs, does not come easily when you and your family live in a shelter for the homeless. ''The children say, 'Mommy, when are we going to get out of here?' '' Ms. Hernandez, 40, said softly, her eyes downcast. ''You see it in their faces: they don't speak, but they show it. They say it's your fault.''

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless, the Gift of Hope

docs.abstract: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund opens its annual campaign; photos (L)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NEW YORK TIMES NEEDIEST CASES FUND

docs.lead_paragraph: With President Bush widely expected to sign soon the first federal law prohibiting a specific abortion procedure, opponents filed three suits on Friday seeking to overturn the imminent ban on the grounds that it would be overly broad and unconstitutional. The suits, filed by three advocacy groups in federal district courts in Nebraska, San Francisco and the Southern District of New York, amount to an unusual pre-emptive strike against Mr. Bush, who is not expected to sign the measure until Wednesday. Experts say legal challenges are rare before a bill becomes law.

headline.main: 3 Suits Filed to Block an Abortion Bill That Bush Intends to Sign

docs.abstract: Planned Parenthood Federation of America, Center for Reproductive Rights and National Abortion Federation sue in three separate federal courts to overturn bill to ban abortion procedure doctors call intact dilation and extraction and critics call partial-birth abortion; act before Pres Bush signs bill, citing need to protect doctors from threat of criminal penalty (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Contrary to what William Saletan charges (''What's the Value of a Fetus?,'' Op-Ed, Oct. 26), abortion rights supporters do not treat the fetus ''as nothing.'' We do not recognize the fetus at all, because there is no one fetus. There are many fetuses, and they do not have equal value.
docs.abstract: Prof Lynn M Morgan letter on William Saletan's Oct 26 article warns bill to ban so-called partial birth abortions values fetus over life of mother
